['Size - Most bacteria range from about 0.5 to 5 micrometers in length.', 'Shape - Common shapes include cocci (spherical), bacilli (rod-shaped), and spirilla (spiral).', 'Arrangement - Bacteria can exist as single cells, or they may form clusters like staphylococci or chains like streptococci.', 'Gram Staining Reaction - Bacteria are classified into two groups based on their cell wall composition which reacts to the Gram stain: Gram-positive (purple) and Gram-negative (pink).', 'Flagella - Some bacteria have one or more flagella, which provide motility', 'Capsule - Many bacteria possess a protective outer layer called a capsule, which is usually composed of polysaccharides and helps in evading host immunity.', 'Spores - Some bacteria can produce spores that allow them to survive extreme conditions such as heat or desiccation; these are typically found among the Gram-positive genera like Bacillus or Clostridium.', 'Cell wall structure – Bacterial cell walls contain peptidoglycan, a polymer consisting of sugars and amino acids that forms an asymmetric mesh providing structural support.', 'Cytoplasmic membrane - The cytoplasmic membrane is the innermost layer that encloses the bacterial cytopamoebas, and it acts as a selective barrier for ions and molecules.', 'Pili or Fimbriae – These hair-like appendages allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces or other cells; they can also be involved in conjugation (a form of genetic exchange).']
